skills.name: Recognise when a number is written in standard form
Write numbers greater than 1 in standard form
Perform subtraction calculations using standard form
Perform division calculations using standard form
Order numbers in standard form that are between 0 and 1

explanations.B: With standard form, remember to look at the number as a whole, not just the first part. For Tom’s numbers, 2.3 × 10⁶ is to a higher power of 10 than 9.3 × 10⁵, which means it has a higher value. explanations.A: I think you have done the subtraction correctly, but just be careful with writing the answer in standard form. The power of 10 is telling you the place value, so a negative power means you are dividing by that power of 10
explanations.B: I think you have subtracted the numbers and powers. Use the powers of 10 to find the place value of all the digits, then you can do the subtraction and put the answer back into standard form
explanations.C: The power that 10 is raised to is different for each bracket, namely 4 and 5. This means that the 3 and 2 have different place values. Write the values as normal numbers then do the subtraction: 30,000 − 200,000 = −170,000. This is −1.7 × 100000 = −1.7 × 10⁵.
explanations.D: Almost, just check what place value column the numbers are in

explanations.A: I think you have added the powers of 10. When we divide we don't add the powers. Think about cancelling down to see what you need to do with the powers
explanations.B: I think you have subtracted the numbers and the powers. Try writing this out as a fraction, and then you can divide the number parts and the powers of 10 separately
explanations.C: Division can be easier to process if it’s expressed in the following way: (3 × 10⁴)/(2 × 10⁵). We can then work out 3/2 and (10⁴)/(10⁵), remembering that when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 1.5 × 10^(4 – 5) = 1.5 × 10⁻¹
explanations.D: Almost, just check you have subtracted the powers the right way round.

explanations.A: Division can be easier to process if it’s expressed in the following way: (4 × 10³)/(5 × 10⁴). We can then work out 4/5 and (10³)/(10⁴), remembering that when dividing indices with the same base number, the powers are subtracted: 0.8 × 10^(3 – 4) = 0.8 × 10⁻¹. Writing this in standard form: 0.8 × 10⁻¹ = 8 × 10⁻¹ × 10⁻¹ = 8 × 10⁻²
explanations.B: I think you have subtracted the numbers and the powers. Try writing this out as a fraction, and then you can divide the number parts and the powers of 10 separately
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied the powers. When dividing we need to subtract the powers of 10. You will need to make sure the number is then put into standard form.
explanations.D: Almost, just check you have subtracted the powers the right way round.
